document.text: Worship services will be at Hollywood Baptist Church Sunday morning July 4 at 9 a.m. Sunday School will follow at 10 oclock. Rev. Paid Balthaaer deliver ed a good message at Hollywood Sunday morning. Friends were deeply grieved to hear of the death of Rev. and Mrs. Clarence Davis infant son. We extend to them our love and deepest sympathy. Deepest sympathy is extend ed the families of Mr. John Ferguson and Mr. Curtis Blackwell. Mrs. Kenneth Deaner and daughters, Delorious Ann and Dawn spent the week end in Newport News with Mrs. loan Mayberry, Mr. and Mrs. Ryland Mayberry and Mrs. Lucy Deaner. Mrs. loan Mayberry accompanied them home for a visit. Mrs. David Austin and Janet were visitors Wednesday mor ning of Mrs. Thomas Woodall and Lisa. Mr. Frank Covington visited Mrs. M. L. Covington and Mrs. W. T. Covington Friday afternoon. Mr. and Mrs. L. L. Webb and Miss Odell Webb called in the W. H. Wingfield home Satur day afternoon. Mr. and Mrs. Twyman Baldwin visited in this home of Mrs. Mary Bagby Saturday night. Visting Mrs. C. R. Ban ton Sunday night were Mr. and Mrs. R. G. Austin and Tom. Mr. and Mrs. H. D. Webb, of Richmond, were guests Sunday of Mr. and Mrs. K. M. Webb and family. Among others visiting Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Woodall and family Sunday were Mr. and Mrs. L. H. Watson, Mr. and Mrs. Scott Sheets and Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Almond. Mr. and Mrs. J. L. Torrence had their children and grand children with them for Fathers Day. Relatives and friends are so glad to hear Mrs. Frank Woodall is home from the hospital. We pray she may soon be well. Miss Joyce Webb spent a few days last week in Lynchburg with Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Woodson. Visting Mr. and Mrs. L. H. Watson Saturday were Mrs. Lee Smith and Mr. and Mrs. Larry Sexton and son. We are very sorry to hear Mr. Bennett Gilliam is back in the Lynchburg Hospital. Rev. and Mrs. Otis Sndtb and Mrs W. T. Covington visited him Sunday afternoon. We wish for him a speedy recovery. Mrs. Ruby Woodson, Lisa and Mrs. M. L. Covington visited Mrs. W. T. Covington last week. Visiting Mr. Frank Coving ton and Mrs. Mary Bagby last week were Mr. and Mrs. James Bartlett, of Texas, Mrs. E. T. Ponton of Roanoke, Rev. Paul Balthaser, David Daniel and Andy Balthaser, Mr. H. W.

document.text: work hard in the vineyard this year. God will bless those that are faith ful and faint not. Quite a crowd of young people f Mr. S. H. Bouton met at the home of------------ Friday night last and enjoyed them selves to their satisfaction. They were honored with the presence of our wide awake merchant, Mr. J. H. Lewis. He was looking after the welfare of his best girl who was one ofthegueets. Miss Olie For a is visiting Miss Mary Agee this week. Mr. AUie Lewis and Miss Maud Wooldridge were visiting at tha homo of Mr. T. H. OBrien Friday and Saturday last. Mr. Maurice OBrien has returned home from the army, where he has been engaged for three years. His relatives and friends were delighted to welcome him back sale and sound once more. This is the second time he has recieved an houorable dis charge. Mr. S. A. Gilliam has left for West Va., where he has employment. His family is still at home. The T im is continues to be praised among our people.  It certainly has improved anf gets more interesting every week. It surely is all the county paper any one could ask for. Bostwisnes for our thoughtful and good Editor, for he deserve lots of praise.

document.text: Wonderful summer this one hurrying to a close. No wetting lain since May and yet never before tueh crops of vegetables and fruits, while well worked corn even on highland are promising good re turns. The rainbow spanned the ky the other day and a working, waiting, trusting farmer saw written upon it in letters of living light,  seed time and harvest and simply sang as he went to his daily tasks. Fine philosophy thatbetter still, fine religion. Onr streets are so smooth that anto drivers cant resist the temp tation to break the speed limit for which they aro mude to pay heavily. But some folk will have fun at any nd every  ost. Mr. Paul Venable, the venerable Confederate of whom 1 have made mention ia your paper, is just now bu y shipping choice cantalopes to t ie city markets upon whioh he makes handsome returns. You may recall that two seasons ago he sold the lettuce fiorn one acre for 1,000. And yet ome young and strong meu complain that its hard work to make even a living on broad acres. It may be that they are too broad, and if the acreage was con densed and more thought given to the working, a refreshing change might follow. Mr. J. J. Gilliam, who was so seriously wounded by a mad bull, ii improving. This in o nuection with the accident is worth repeating. O i the morning of the day when tne injury was received, an orphan b y began to work on his farm, was with him at the time, and and was told to run for his life. Instead of this, however, he seized the fork whioh Mr. Gilliam had for his own protection, drove it deep into the animals nose and so disarming him for further fighting. Of auoh stuff are the worlds herooi made. Rev. W. E. Hill did spend one Sunday in Farmville and preached twice at the Presbyterian church to the delight of the large congrega tions that were privileged to hear k.n. Mr. B. M. Cox, Dr. Hamlet and oiuors are c mping on the banks of the mill pond again and indulging that bolds chief charm for them. izidC Walton never had more de voted or more loyal disciples. W hether the fish bite or not still the fun never wates. Hope deferred d can, make their hearts sick, for they are expecting a catch to follow the next bite. The motor ear of Mr. R. B. Johns ha? been much in demand of late. When a fity mile spin is desired he rattles off the distance as though it was but a few m.les in the country. A Wilson Club is being organized bat as everybody is for Wilson in this section it hardly seems neces sary. The principal object, how ever, will be to raiai a campaign fund. Peoples money for the peo ples man will make a peoples Presi dent. The sweet cider train has arrived well laden with the pi ince of sum mer drinks. Three days old, and made of ripe apples and no French wine beats it. I confess, however, that I would prefer having it direct from the old time trongh rather than the modern day cider mill. A hail storm just now such as they had in Culpeper recently would play havoc in this section. And so far as Im advised insurance against hail is not oommon this season. Mr. and Mrs. W. P. Richardson are spending the week at the home of Mr. Joe Hazlegrove, Cumberland, preserving, piekling and canning lor winter rse. Mr. Hazlegrove has an abundant fruit crop and divid-.s liberally with his neighbors and friends. Some men do believe that it is more blessed to give than re ceive. Rev. W. L. Wayts has returned from Spring Creek Church where he conducted a successful meeting. Rev. Proctor is greatly improved by hiB stay in the mountains. Mrs. Dr. Gils and the boy hav returned from Virginia Beaoh. Mrs. Dr. Irving and Miss Mary Jackson drove to the country home of Dr. Chas. Blanton, of Richmond, in Cumberland, and spent the day. Perhaps a thirty mile drive, out they held the reins over a peerless roads ter. Mr. S. H. Davis, wife and daugh ter, of MoAlpine, W. Va., are visit ing in the home of Mr. Baxter Davis. document.text: with friends and doing some spring shopping. Mr. E. W. Gilliam, of Lynch burg, was a visitor here Sun day. Mrs. J. H. McCue returned from Bluefield, W. Va., on last Friday from a weeks visit to Mrs. O. 0. Jenkins, who has been quite ill for the past two weeks. Mr. J. W. Davis returned last week from Staunton, having spent several days with his son Prof. J. Talmage Davis, of the 8taunton Military Institute. Mrs. James Glenn, of Olive Branch, was called to the home of her father, Mr. Ben Rosser, who was reported as being quite siok on last Friday, and the many friends of Mr. Rosser are made more sad to learn of the serious accident to one of his sons,Mr. Bob Rosser, of Lynchburg, who, while rid ing a motorcycle, collided with an automobile, causing the loss of one leg, one broken arm and a severe cut on the head. Our citizens in this part of the county, on both north and south side of Appomattox river, are worked up to a point that our officials can not bring up the same old chestnut that is always politely handed to the farmer You havnot ask ed for anything, so why do you kick? And from what I have seen and heard, the citizens of this part of Clover Hill Dis trict will not be satisfied with nothing less than a good bridge across Appomattox riv er near the poi-t known as the John Marshall ford, and a com  mittee of 15 of the old straight liners has been appointed to meet with the Board of Super visors at their regular meeting and investigate further into the matter. And since your correspondent has somewhat the resemblance of Foxy Grandpa, I will say nothing as to finances. Mr. and Mrs. J. W. Harden, Miss Alice Harden and Mr Turner, of Fife, are on a visit to Mrs. Hardens mother, Mrs J. W. Harwood. Rev. Mr. Sam Harwood and wife and Mrs. Laokford, of! Jarretts, are also on a visit to Mrs. Harwood. Miss Ruth Harwood, of Hope well, spent the week-end with home people. Mr. J. R. Fore was down to Gamp Lee on Thursday.

document.text: Winners in The Virginia Farmer, Yesterday and Today are pictured above with Mrs. Frances Gilliam representing the Appomattox County Farm Bureau Womens Committee. Pictured are Ronald Thornhill, 1st place Tom Cobb, 2nd place and Michelle Ford, 3rd place. Over 40 4th and 5th grade 4-H members entered posters in the contest sponsored jointly by the Farm Bureau Womens Committee and Appomattox County 4-H clubs. In addition to the top three winners who received cash awards of 5, 3, and 2, the following 4-ITers entered posters Blue ribbon winners Sally Coleman, Chuck Thompson.. Tammy Childress, Cheryl Mathews. Red award winners Shelia Woodson, Suzette Ranson, Rose Christian, Susan jygin, Joe Crews, Chris Tolley, Courtney Franklin, Keith McCormick, Latonia Richardson, Ronald Kelso, Stephen Hamlett, and Carrie Pennington. document.text: Winners in the Patchwork Pillow contest sponsored by the Appomattox County Farm Bureau Womens Committee were in the 20 and up category. First prize of 5.0Q went to Mrs. Frances Dyess, second prize to Mrs. Frances Gilliam, and third prize went to Mrs. Fannie Farrar. The contest was held at the annual Farm Bureau picnic and was judged by Mrs. Geraldine Marshall and Mrs. Jim Smith. The Farm Bureau Farm Family poster contest for Farm Bureau children was sponsored by the Womens Committee
